moves.1. e4: I was playing as black ... In this short game, I put all my focus on moving my forces to attack whites king
moves.2. g3: I don't like this move as if the goal is to fianchetto the bishop, the g2-b7 diagonal is already blocked by the e4 pawn
moves.2... Nf6: attacking the e4 pawn thus gaining an early initiative and gaining more of the center
moves.3. Nc3: defending the e4 pawn and developing a piece toward the center
moves.3... Bc5: developing the dark-squared bishop to an important diagonal ... especially if white castles king-side
moves.4. Qf3: moving the queen too early in the game ... but maybe, white was afraid of Ng4 thus pressuring the f2 pawn and possibly forking queen and rook
moves.4... d6: opening lines to the light-squared bishop
moves.5. Bh3: trying to catch-up with the development race.
moves.5... Bxh3: first bloodshed in the battle ... I cannot afford to lose the initiative and play passively ... I may have played Nb-d7 but this will give him the initiative
moves.6. Nxh3: now he has a non-defended knight on edge ... which is not good
moves.7. O-O: castling king side ... which is fine for me as I placed the dark-squared bishop on c5 for that reason ... it is now when my plan became more clearer ... and the plan is simple ... 1.castle queen-side 2. attack king-side toward whites king
moves.7... Nd4: temporarily forking the queen and the c2 pawn ... but most importantly, this move puts my knight on a very attacking place nearer whites king
moves.8. Qd3: defending the c2 pawn ... notice the queen moved twice till now, while I spent these two moves on a better placement of my forces
moves.8... Qd7:
this move helps me both tactically and strategically

Tactically:
getting the queen off my first rank while preserving the initiative by attacking the lone knight on h3 

Strategically:
getting nearer to achieve my plan (1. castle queen-side 2. attack king-side toward whites king)
moves.9... O-O-O:
mission 1 accomplished ... queen-side castle completed.

moving to mission 2. attack king side toward whites king
moves.10. Ne2: spending a move to challenge my well-placed knight on d4
moves.10... Rdg8: sticking to my plan ... moving the rook to g8 to support a pawn thrust toward whites king. note how all my pieces points out to whites king-side. here I realized that I am going to win this match :-)
moves.11. Nxd4: removing an important attacker ... but, who cares
moves.11... Bxd4: taking back with the bishop to keep the dark diagonal open
moves.12... Bb6: moving the bishop to a place far from small harrasements, while keeping the diagonal open
moves.13. f3: I am not sure of the intent of this move, but I think the aim is to add a defender to the e4 pawn and make some space to the knight on h3 to breath
moves.14... h5: normal continuation of the pawn thrust ... I want to open lines for my rooks to attack the king
moves.15. b3: irrelevant ... the battle is not here
moves.15... hxg4: opening lines and attacking the bad knight on h3
moves.17... Rxh3: taking the kinght and attacking the queen
moves.18... Qxg1#: checkmate ... I hope you enjoyed the game
